On 28 August 2013 06:01,  <lehman.154@...> wrote:
>
> I like the idea of exploring different mechanisms for encouraging diversity
> during search, and geography is an interesting structure that could be used
> for such a purpose. I imagine what you are suggesting goes beyond the
> typical idea of island models or other diversity mechanisms where the
> environment within each geographical niche is typically the same.

For starters I was thinking of a homogeneous space and investigating
the dynamics that emerge. Later on we can imagine adding structure to
the geo-space, and islands would be an important form of structure -
they foster diversity, but to allow some mixing we could connect
'islands' with 'causeways', or just put an wall between two regions
with a small opening.


> That is, one of the most interesting things from an evolutionary perspective
> about different geographical regions of the world is that what strategies
> are adaptive changes between them. In other words, altitude and temperature
> and chemical composition vary with geography, which might correspondingly
> vary the attractors for optimizing fitness. In this way, across all
> different geographies you might encounter a wide range of cool strategies
> that are all locally well-adapted.

Yes and I see this as a later research spin-off, building on work that
focuses on a simple homogeneous space. But you could certainly imagine
smooth transitions in the parameters to allow agents to evolve in
'easier' environments and gradually migrate (and coloniose) more
difficult regions in the space. That's like a form of incremental
evolution where traditionally we artificially 'bumped up' the object
function's difficult as the population fitness passed certain
milestone thresholds.


> If I correctly recall an earlier discussion, you were at one point
> interested in different geographical niches where selection would vary among
> them, e.g. there would be some differences between the environments within
> each niche. That way, the overall search might be more non-objective because
> it is not driven to any one super-organism but in finding interesting
> solutions within all of the different niches.

That's right. That idea was very similar and a variation on this
current one (i.e. another spin-off research direction), the idea there
was two have multiple objective fn's related to what you wanted to
achieve, so if I want a walker then I might measure (1) ability to
achieve a standing position, (2) distance traversed in N seconds, (3)
energy expended. Measure all three seperately, and then place the
genom ein a 3D cube where each metric represents an axis in 3D space.
Now we can reproduce amongst genomes in similar parts of the space and
hopefully we get genomes migrate towards the corner of the cube that
represents high fitness in all three metrics - but before then we get
colonies in all other corners (good on some metrics, not on others),
and maybe some in the middle (mediocre on all metrics).



> In Ken and I's virtual creature paper, novelty was measured in how different
> a virtual creature's morphology was from others in the population, using a
> coarse small-dimensional space of morphologies (e.g. their height and mass).

I see that as behavioural (or 'strategy') space, which is orthogonal
to geo-space, e.g. a single piece of land can have plants on it that
compete with each other for sunlight, water and ground nutrients, but
they don't compete with mammals for sunlight, and mammals don't
compete with insects, etc. So in any one region in geo-space we can
have a range of diverse survival strategies, some of which directly
compete (e.g. lions and hyenas) and some which largely don't care
about each other (lions versus plants)


> However, instead of a morphology space where the underlying evaluation
> environment is uniform (e.g. the world any creature is evaluated in is
> exactly the same), you could also have something like you are suggesting,
> where the evaluation environment varies over a space (e.g. some environments
> in one part of the geographic space could be hilly and others in a different
> area, flat).

All good and valid variations, with a common root - a simple
homogeneous geo-space. Baby steps.

Colin.
